There are a lot of factors that come into play when evaluating a mock
framework. You will probably
find these somewhere online (because I am pretty sure somebody with more
writting skills have already published it). So, I will just say that my
personal ranking is EasyMock 2.x (clean API, clean design, legibility, but
it works only on VM >= 1.5), EasyMock 1.x (not so clean API, still clean
design, legibility), JMock 1.x and JMock 2.x (this one is imo a mess: they
moved from string-based method invocation to more static approach, but they
have completely screwed the API). However, as I said, this is my personal
opinion :-).

bests,

./alex
--
.w( the_mindstorm )p.
  TestNG co-founder
EclipseTestNG Creator


On 5/2/07, James Abley <james.abley@...> wrote:
>
>   Hi all,
>
> I'm looking to use a Mock framework. I was using a home-grown one with
> a previous employer, but that isn't (yet - I'm hopeful!) open-sourced
> / externally available, so I need to make a jump to another one.
>
> I tried EasyMock (1.x) after reading JB's book a couple of years back
> - I think the state of the art has moved on somewhat since then.
>
> The closed framework that I used previously seems pretty similar in
> terms of look and feel to rMock 2.0 and JMock 2.0, but I'm open to
> other suggestions.
>
> What experiences to people have to share?
>
> Cheers,
>
> James
>  
>
